member.name: IResourceManager.CancelRequest

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The CancelRequest method cancels the request for a resource.

member.param: Resource identifier of a pending request.
Pointer to the interface that made the request.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.NotifyAcquire

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The NotifyAcquire method notifies the resource manager that an attempt to acquire a resource has completed.

member.param: Token for the registered resource.
Pointer to the interface of the object requesting the resource.
Value indicating the success of the acquisition; S_OK if the resource was acquired, or an error value if not.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.NotifyRelease

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The NotifyRelease method notifies the resource manager that has released a resource.

member.param: Resource token.
Pointer to the object releasing the resource.
Flag that specifies whether the resource is still required. Set to TRUE to indicate that you still want the resource when it is next available, or FALSE if you no longer want the resource.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.Register

Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The Register method registers a single named resource with the resource manager.

member.param: Named resource.
Number of resources.
Pointer to the returned token identifying the resource to be used in additional calls.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.RegisterGroup

Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The RegisterGroup method registers a named resource group with the resource manager.

member.param: Named resource group.
Number of resources in the group.
Pointer to an array of resources in the group.
Pointer to the returned group resource identifier.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.ReleaseFocus

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The ReleaseFocus method sets the focus object to NULL in the resource manager if the current focus object is the one specified in this method.

member.param: Pointer to the focus object.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

member.name: IResourceManager.RequestResource

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The RequestResource method requests the use of a given registered resource.

member.param: Resource token retrieved when the resource was registered.
Pointer to the IUnknown interface of a focus object associated with a request (typically the IUnknown interface of the filter).
Pointer to the interface on the object requesting the resource.
member.returns: Returns an HRESULT value. Returns S_OK if the requested resource is returned, or S_FALSE if the resource is not available, in which case the resource manager will call the requesting object back when the resource becomes available. Any other return is an error.

member.name: IResourceManager.SetFocus

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The SetFocus method notifies the resource manager that a specified object has been given the focus of the user.

member.param: Pointer to the object that has been given the user's focus.

returns.para: Returns an HRESULT value that depends on the implementation. HRESULT can be one of the following standard constants, or other values not listed.

summary.para: [The feature associated with this page, DirectShow, is a legacy feature. It has been superseded by MediaPlayer, , and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation. Those features have been optimized for Windows 10 and Windows 11. Microsoft strongly recommends that new code use MediaPlayer, IMFMediaEngine and Audio/Video Capture in Media Foundation instead of DirectShow, when possible. Microsoft suggests that existing code that uses the legacy APIs be rewritten to use the new APIs if possible.]
The IResourceManager interface resolves contentions for system resources.

The filter graph manager exposes this interface. Filters can use this interface to request resources that other objects are likely to use. For example, audio renderers use this interface to resolve contentions for the wave-output device, to enable sound to follow focus.
Applications will typically not use this interface.

An object can use this interface to resolve possible contentions between existing resources. The object registers the resource with the interface and then requests it whenever needed. The object should notify the filter graph manager whenever the user focus changes. The filter graph manager can then switch contended resources to the objects that have the focus of the user.

An object that uses this interface must implement the interface. IResourceConsumer provides a callback mechanism for the filter graph manager to notify the object when a resource becomes available, or when the object should release a resource that it acquired.
